quote: Captain's Log, Stardate 51474.2    The Defiant has been ordered to    investigate a rare subspace    compression phenomenon recently    discovered in Federation space.
Three of my officers are taking a    runabout into the anomaly's    vortex.
So... how small are they?
The miniaturization process won't    begin until the runabout reaches    the edge of the accretion disk.
I see. And then they'll begin...    shrinking?
Yes, sir.
Major Kira, are you laughing at our    investigation of this subspace    anomaly?
No, sir!
Glad to hear it.
The data collected here could    provide Starfleet with the key to    creating transwarp corridors    through space. It would give us    a substantial tactical advantage    over the Dominion.
Very important research.
What? I'm not laughing.        I'm not.        Just because we're... shrinking    three people down to the size of    coffee cups...
Smaller, actually.
I do not see what is so humorous    about... being small.
Neither do I.
Rubicon to Defiant.
(regaining his     composure)    On screen.
Their visual signal's degrading,    captain. We have audio only.
Go ahead, Rubicon.
We're about to enter the accretion    disk.
I wish I could be there with you,    old man.
I'll send you a postcard. Tell    Worf I look forward to hearing his    poem...
I'll bet it'll be .    We'll talk to you again once we've    left  and    reversed the (effect of    compression.) Rubicon
Good luck, Rubicon.
We've lost their signal, captain.
Thank you, ensign.        Poem?
It is an... ancient Klingon    tradition to compose a poem to    commemorate an important event.    Jadzia asked me to compose one for    this occasion.
What have you got so far?
They've penetrated the accretion    disk.
Is it my imagination, or did the    kid just cover for him?
This could be the beginning of a    beautiful friendship.
They're getting smaller.
Even the space within their    subatomic structure is shrinking.
I wonder what it feels like.
I don't feel any smaller.
Well, believe it or not, you're    about a meter tall and shrinking    fast. In a few minutes, you'll be    half the size of a combadge.
There's a comforting thought.
The gamma ray flux is increasing.    We should close the blast    shutters.
Take a last look. We're on    sensors from here on.
Now you're certain we'll return to    normal size when we leave the    anomaly?
Our probes did. You saw the data.        Something wrong?
I'm fine.        I'm just not in love with the idea    of... being small.
What are you smirking at? You're    as small as I am.
Actually, you're sitting one-point-   one-four meters closer to the    focal point of the anomaly. That    means you've shrunk point zero    four percent more than I have.
What was that?
The tractor beam is fluctuating.    Something's wrong.
The Jem'Hadar is coming around for    another pass.
Return fire, Mister Worf. Nog,    pull the Rubicon out of there.
The radiation from the vortex must    have masked their warp signature.
Phasers are off-line.
We're a sitting duck as long as    we're tethered to the runabout.
I'm not going to leave them in    there if I can help it. Worf, get    down to auxiliary control and    target the phasers manually.
(struggling with his     panel)    I'm losing the Rubicon, sir!
If we're going to get out of here,    I need warp power now!
I'm on it!
Shield generators and impulse    engines are off-line, Captain.         Warp engines, too.
Surrender or you will all be    killed.
Chief?
You okay?
I think so.
Julian?
I'm fine. You're not.
That's better.
That was the easy part.
The good news is we're still    alive, so we must have escaped the    anomaly.
The bad news is that external    sensors and the com system are    down. I can patch around some of    the damage, but it'll take time.
Add the blast shutters to your    list. I can't get them open.
There you go. Good as new.
I don't suppose that thing'll work    on our communications system.
I'm picking up the Defiant's    transponder signal. We can home    in on it.
Going to one-quarter impulse.    Chief, either open these shutters    or give me external sensors --    whichever's quicker. I need to    see where we're going.
The bridge is secure.
Tactical report.

Their bridge officers are confined    in the mess hall; other survivors    in the cargo bay. We will have    impulse power back on line in    thirty minutes, but it will take    several hours to restore warp    capability.
It must be gratifying for an    "Elder," to end his career with a    victory.        I feel privileged to be here with    you at such a moment.
There is still much to do before    we declare victory. Until we    leave Federation space, we are    vulnerable to --
I am the First. And I have    declared victory.
That is, of course, your    prerogative.
Open a channel to the Vorta.
We have the boarding party.
Ah, First. Your report?
The Defiant is ours.

Good. Very, very good. I must    admit, I was initially quite    skeptical about you and the other    new Jem'Hadar bred in this    quadrant. But this is a most    impressive debut.        Wouldn't you agree, Elder?
The takeover of the ship was    competently executed.
Do I detect a note of jealousy in    your voice? I'm sure it must be    difficult for you to watch a new    race of Jem'Hadar beginning to    supplant you and the other members    of the old guard.
I serve the Founders. If it is    their will to create a new race,    that is the order of things.
But... ?
But the Jem'Hadar bred here in the    Alpha Quadrant have not proven    themselves superior to those from    the Gamma Quadrant. At least...    not yet.
Not yet? It was the Alphas who    made this victory possible. If    not for us, you would've never --
You two can argue about this on    your own time.        First, how long until you restore    warp power?
I am about to assess the damage.    I will make a complete survey of    the ship and give you a report in    one hour.
Very well. I await your report.
Bring me Captain Sisko.
I would suggest to you that his    execution can wait until we have    completed repairs to the ship.
I'm not going to execute him.
Are you about to question my    orders... Second?
No. Obedience brings Victory.
And Victory is Life.
Find the ship's transponder and    shut it down -- I don't want    anyone tracking us. And get these    chairs off the bridge.
That's enough. Thanks.
I should've foreseen this. I    should have sent out    reconnaissance probes to scan for    enemy ships. Or a shuttle. Or    re-calibrated our sensors. If    I had, Jadzia would...
None of that would've done any    good. The Jem'Hadar approached us    from the anterior angle of the    anamoly; their warp signatures    were--
He's only trying to tell you it's    not your fault.
I do not need him to tell me    anything.

Everybody, relax. First of all,    we don't know what happened to the    Rubicon. They might've gotten out    of the anomaly on their own. If    they did, they could be halfway    home and in a lot better shape    than we are. So let's just hold    off analyzing our mistakes for    now.
If they restore warp power, we'll    be analyzing them in a Dominion    prison camp.

Restoring warp power may not be so    simple for them. It took us a    week just to learn how to pilot    one of their ships. So we might    still have a chance to retake the    Defiant. But we can't do anything    unless we get out of this room.         Suggestions?
Captain Sisko. Come with me.
Just sit tight, everyone. I'll be    back.
We've lost the Defiant's    transponder signal.
Coming to full stop.
The problem's not on our end.    They must have stopped    transmitting.
I can't keep flying blind, Chief.
Try the shutters.
Nice work.
Ask and ye shall receive.
What the hell is that?
Some kind of wall.
In the middle of nowhere?
(peering up and to the     right).   Wait a minute. There's a symbol   up there.
It looks like... a large black   circle.
Anything else?
Hold on.
Chief, you're not going to like   this...
I thought you said we'd return to    our normal size when we left the    anomaly.
We should have.
We didn't leave the anomaly by the    same path that we entered it...
... so the process failed to    reverse itself.
Are you telling me that I'm going    to be...
... this bloody tall for the rest    of my life?
This bloody tall, actually.       Don't worry. All we have to do to    regain our normal size is re-enter    the anomaly and follow our    original trajectory back out.
In theory.
In theory.
Tell you what isn't a theory --    we're going to need the Defiant's    help to re-enter the anomaly.
With communications out, how do we    get their attention?
We could fly up to a window and    knock.
Well, if we're this big...
... that means the Rubicon is about    this big.
More or less.
Well, the Defiant's aft plasma    vent is...
... this big.
Are you suggesting we take the    Runabout inside the Defiant?
Why not? Getting past the anti-   backflow valve may be a bit    tricky. But we'll have a better    chance of getting someone's    attention inside than we will    sitting out here.
I love it. Let's go.
The engineering team reports that    we can restart the impulse engines    in twelve minutes.
Good.
Captain Benjamin Sisko. The one    the Bajorans call the Emissary.

I am First Kudak'Etan. In a    strange way, you are the reason I    exist. If you had not eliminated    our fleet in the wormhole, there    would have been no need to breed    Alpha Quadrant Jem'Hadar.
You didn't bring me here to say    "thank you."

No. The impulse engines sustained    only minor damage in our attack,    but the warp drive has been    severely damaged. I need your    technical expertise in order to    repair it.        Take the captain to the Engine    Room and let him begin the    necessary repairs.
That's a mistake. Giving him    access to the Engine Room will    only give him an opportunity to    retake the ship.        In fact, he's working on a plan at    this very moment.
I was not aware that telepathy was    a Gamma characteristic.
I know what he's thinking because    it's exactly what I would be doing    in his position. You should kill    him now, before he has a chance to    put his plan into motion.
You are the Second. I am the    First. Do not presume to tell me    what to do.
I'm glad that you two have sorted    that out. Now, what makes you    think I'm going to help you?
Your choice is to repair the warp    drive or watch me execute your    crew one at a time.
Have Sixth Duran'Adar select one    of the prisoners for execution and    bring him to the bridge!
I can't do this job alone. I'm    going to need some of my crew.
How many?
First. I... "strongly suggest"    that you refuse this request.
You have the weapons. Are you    afraid you can't handle a few    unarmed prisoners?
I won't be baited by a prisoner.        And you shouldn't either.

Okay. I'm in no hurry to reach a    Dominion prison camp. You want me    to teach your men how to repair    the warp drive, that's fine with    me. We'll begin with the primary    command and control systems --    that should take about six hours.    Then we'll work our way up to    basic engineering theory for a    class seven warp drive, then --
Enough. You may have the three    other Bridge officers, but that's    all.        And I am not interested in any    more of your "suggestions." Now    take him to the Engine Room.
So where are we, Chief?
We've just about reached the bi-   polar flow junction.        I think.
You think?
I'm not used to seeing things from    this... perspective.
Once we reach the flow junction we    should be able to go up into the    secondary warp plasma feed and    then exit through the diagnostic    panel.
This conduit is filthy, Chief.    Don't you ever clean in here?
All right, all right. Let's not    badger the chief.
Thank you.
Sorry. It was very... small of    me.
Whatever it is you're planning --    don't. I'll be watching you and    at the first sign of treachery    I'll kill all three of your bridge    officers.
I'm a prisoner. I have no    intention of --
The First may be a fool, but I am    not.
Then it's a pity for you that    you're not the First.
I was... until two days ago. If    we had captured you while I was in    command... we wouldn't be having    this conversation.        Deck two, section five.
So what happened?
He is an Alpha, I am a Gamma. His    DNA and psychological profile are    specifically designed for combat    in this quadrant. The Founders    believe that makes him a better    leader.
What do you believe?
I believe I've given you enough    information already.
We have restored impulse power,    and the warp drive will be    operational in five hours.
Excellent. It's good to see my    faith in you has not been    misplaced. The Founders will be    pleased.
If you require no more assistance,    I will resume our mission to    Coridan.        Let's hope the Federation's    dilithium miners will be as    surprised to see us as the    Defiant's crew was.
Victory is Life.
Indeed.
Set course for the closest    Dominion outpost. Engage impulse    engines.
Can you give me a hand with this?
How do you tell the Alphas from    the Gammas?
The captain said their upgrades    were internal.        When I get a chance, I'll kill a    pair of them and look inside.
If they're breeding Jem'Hadar in    this quadrant, the Dominion won't    have to worry about bringing any    reinforcements through the    wormhole.
True.
Then that means the Jem'Hadar will    outnumber us before too long.
They probably do already.
Great.
Don't let it concern you. It will    only be a problem for you if you    survive this mission.
I'm glad you're not morale    officer.
Uh, oh.
What is it?
The magnetic plasma guides are    heating up.
They must've initiated the impulse    prestart sequence.
What does that mean?
It means this entire conduit is    about to be filled with    superheated plasma.
When you say superheated...
Unless I can find another way out    of here, we'll be vaporized. Is    that clear enough?
Crystal.
There's a distribution manifold    coming up... take the left    conduit, then make a quick right    into the relays.
Left, then right.
I hope you know where you're    going, Chief.
So do I.
Through the relays... there's an    inspection hatch coming up on the    right. Now if I can figure out a    way to open the hatch...
We're out of time.
What about the hatch?
We'll have to open it the old-   fashioned way...
Let's... not do that again.
No promises.         So where are we, Chief?
We should be in the Engine Room...    near the warp core.
Right. There's the core. Looks    like the warp drive is off-line.
Quite a mess. I wonder what    happened?
What are you doing?
Re-aligning the dilithium    articulation frame.
Instruct him on how to complete    the re-alignment.
It'll take longer to explain, than    it will to --
Then explain it quickly. Now give    him the tool.
All right. Start by decoupling    the lateral microbrace...
That's not good.
Okay, the ship has been boarded.    Chief, I need visual sensors as    fast as you can give them to me.
Right. Julian, give me a hand    down here.
Okay, you should have visual    sensors now, and the com system is    back on-line.
They're forcing our people to    repair the warp drive...
Why's the captain going along with    it?
Good question. But, if I know    Benjamin, he's up to something.         Can you give me a tight shot of    the operations display?
I think so.
You see what I see?
Very clever.
The only problem is, it's not    going to work.
The security codes are hard-wired    into the encryption circuitry.
Is anyone going to let me in on    this conversation?
The captain's trying to take    control of the ship from    Engineering.
Kira's the only one actually    working on the warp drive, and it    doesn't look like she's in much of    a hurry to get it done.
I think Worf's trying to cover    their tracks. It looks like he's    sending false signals through the    computer system.
Nog is the key. He's trying to    override the bridge lockout and    release the codes. Once he does    that, the captain can run the    entire ship from the operations    console.
Nog's a smart kid, but he doesn't    know the Defiant's security    protocols like I do. It'll take    him weeks to release the command    codes from down here.
Can we do anything to help him?
Not from the engine room. If we    could get to the bridge we could    release the codes from there.
How?
One thing at a time. First, we    have to leave the engine room    without getting caught.
Why is the Klingon working on the    plasma display subsystem?
scene: 53   INT. DEFIANT - ENGINE ROOM - OPERATIONS STATION

quote: Because I told him to.
scene: 53   INT. DEFIANT - ENGINE ROOM - OPERATIONS STATION

quote: That system has nothing to do with    warp drive operation.
scene: 53   INT. DEFIANT - ENGINE ROOM - OPERATIONS STATION

quote: Maybe not on Dominion ships, but    I'll need to use the display to    monitor warp plasma stability.
scene: 53   INT. DEFIANT - ENGINE ROOM - OPERATIONS STATION

quote: Now what?
Now we wait until someone walks    out that door.
Sixth.
scene: 57   INT. DEFIANT - ENGINE ROOM - OPERATIONS STATION

quote: Relieve the Klingon. Take over    the repair of the display    subsystem.
scene: 57   INT. DEFIANT - ENGINE ROOM - OPERATIONS STATION

quote: Give the Klingon another task.
scene: 57   INT. DEFIANT - ENGINE ROOM - OPERATIONS STATION

quote: Why?
scene: 57   INT. DEFIANT - ENGINE ROOM - OPERATIONS STATION

quote: Because I said so.
scene: 57   INT. DEFIANT - ENGINE ROOM - OPERATIONS STATION

quote: Why isn't the warp drive on-line    yet?
scene: 57   INT. DEFIANT - ENGINE ROOM - OPERATIONS STATION

quote: He's stalling.
scene: 57   INT. DEFIANT - ENGINE ROOM - OPERATIONS STATION

quote: Stalling? Your Second is the one    who's slowing down the work. He    countermands my orders,    arbitrarily reassigns my crew --    I can't get any work done in here.
scene: 57   INT. DEFIANT - ENGINE ROOM - OPERATIONS STATION

quote: You were told to watch them, not    interfere with them.
scene: 57   INT. DEFIANT - ENGINE ROOM - OPERATIONS STATION

quote: You're playing right into his    hands. Don't you see that?
scene: 57   INT. DEFIANT - ENGINE ROOM - OPERATIONS STATION

quote: Captain Sisko, you have thirty    minutes to restore warp power,    or...        I will kill her, and then another    of your crew every fifteen minutes    until you do.        And you will no longer interfere    with their work.
scene: 57   INT. DEFIANT - ENGINE ROOM - OPERATIONS STATION

quote: Okay... get ready... when he    activates the door sensor, we'll --
Nice bit of piloting.
If you liked that, you're going to    love what's coming up next...
Any luck, ensign?

Not yet, sir. The system's always    three steps ahead of me. Every    time I get past the primary    security net, the secondary kicks    me back out... and then the codes    are reset, and I have to start all    over again...
... like that.
Do we have a backup plan in case    this doesn't work?
Yes. I'll destroy the ship.
There are still a few algorithms    I haven't tried yet.
Thanks.
Okay. I'm ready to connect the    deuterium injector. Go to the    plasma relay and power it up    slowly, just like I showed you.
I'm about ten minutes away from    initiating the prestart sequence    on the warp drive. How's Nog    doing?
Not good. You need to find    another problem.
Too fast! Re-initialize the    system and start again, but do it    at about half the speed this time.
He's not stupid. He's already got    the entire command and control    system committed to memory. I    can't keep him fooled forever.
In a battle of wits between you    and him -- I'll bet on you every    time.
What kind of odds are you giving?
First?
I've realigned the targeting    sensors. There were errors in the    tracking subroutines.
You were not ordered to check the    targeting sensors.
I thought it a wise precaution...    in case we encountered an enemy    ship on our way home.
Your initiative pleases me. It's    a trait that the Gammas lack.
The Gammas have many flaws.
When we return from this mission,    there will be need for a new    Second. I will recommend you to    the Vorta.
You will not be disappointed.
I'm sure that I won't. It'll be    Alphas like us who will determine    the future of this quadrant. That    will be the new order of things.
Looks like we need another ticket    into the bridge.
So how long do we wait for someone    to open the door?
We don't.
I cannot access the auto-destruct    system without drawing attention.
Plant a computer virus in the warp    plasma subprocessor. Set it to    cause a core breach once the ship    reaches warp one.
Understood.
Don't hit it too hard, you could    shatter the control panel.
Don't worry. I've got a light    touch.
Not according to Worf.
Well, we certainly can't release    the control lock while the First    has his hand on it.
Can we bypass it?
I suppose I could reroute the    encryption subprocessors    manually.
But... ?

But, I'll have to leave the ship    to do it. And I have to say I'm    not fond of the idea. I can think    of about a thousand ways a one-   centimeter man could get fried    walking around inside a circuit    housing.

Relax, Miles. You couldn't go    outside even if you wanted to.    You wouldn't be able to breathe.    The oxygen molecules out there are    almost two thousand times bigger    than anything your hemoglobin can    assimilate. You'd suffocate.
Oh. Well, that takes care of that    idea.
Unless...        Circuit housings are airtight.    I could beam a bubble of    compressed oxygen down ahead of    you and it would expand to fill    the housing.
Should work. The air would be    thin, but you'd be able to breathe    for about twenty minutes.
And then?
You pass out.
You mean "we" pass out.        You're coming with me.
This might take longer than I    thought.
All right. If we beamed into the    primary safeties junction, then we    should see a cluster of hueristic    subprocessors next to a    rectilinear expansion module.
The question is, what does a    rectilinear expansion module look    like when you're one centimeter    tall?
I haven't the faintest idea.
But it's amazing, isn't it? Like    we're standing in the middle of an    optronic forest...
All right. It looks like we have    to go...        Julian -- stop!
That chip behind you is carrying    twenty microamps of electric    current. Not very much...
... but enough to fry every synapse    in my tiny little body.        Thanks for the safety tip.
Just step straight forward, away    from the chip.       All right, you're clear.
Now stay right behind me. And    don't touch anything without    asking.
Believe me, I won't.
The White.
It is time.
How's it coming, Chief?
We're... making progress. Aren't    we, Chief?
I'm still trying to locate the...    security protocol interlinks.    Shouldn't be... much longer.
The sooner the better. Things are    getting a little crowded up here.
Here.
We pledge our loyalty to the   Founders from --
We are all Alphas here. Our    loyalty is demonstrated by our    actions, not our words.
All right... now...
Miles.        We're lost, aren't we?
Yes, we're lost!        I can draw these circuits in my    sleep. But I've never seen them    from this... perspective.
Disorientation is one of the...    effects of... hypoxia -- lack    of... oxygen. Need to focus...    on a... landmark.
There. That large isolinear chip.        Number eight-five-nine-six-six-   stroke delta. What is it?
Julian, there are two dozen six-   six-delta's in the asymmetric    encryption circuits alone.
Okay. Then what's...
... what's that down by the base?
A four-way interlink shunt.
So that would mean that the chip    is...
(stares at the     component)    I don't know... I told you, they    all look the same!
All right... then... don't look at    it.
What?
Close your eyes... and use your    memory.
Okay... a four-way shunt at the    base of a...       ... eight-five-nine-six-six-stroke-   delta... isolinear chip would have    to be where?
The only four-way shunt near a six-   six-delta is... at the base of...    the master differential relay.
The only four-way shunt near a six-   six-delta is... at the base of...    the master differential relay.
That has to be it.
So the... interlink we want has to    be... ?
This way.
We've got trouble. They're cross-   checking the diagnostic protocols.
Has Nog made any progress?
Not yet.
Stuck...

quote: Which... one... ?
scene: 87   INT. OPTRONIC CIRCUITY - CLOSE ON O'BRIEN

quote: That... no.        That.
scene: 87   INT. OPTRONIC CIRCUITY - CLOSE ON O'BRIEN

quote: You... sure... ?
scene: 87   INT. OPTRONIC CIRCUITY - CLOSE ON O'BRIEN

quote: Dammit!       Again... then... I'll...

quote: Rub... Rubicon... mi... mi...    mission... complete...

quote: Oh, I am good.
All of you, step away from the    consoles. Right now!
Captain. I did it! I don't know    how, but I released the command    codes.
Well done. What we need now is a    diversion before they go to warp.
Silence!
All the Defiant's command    functions have been transferred to    Engineering.        But nothing's happening.
Maybe the captain hasn't realized    he has control of the ship yet.
Or maybe he's in trouble. The    First was called to the engine    room a few minutes ago.
How long has the warp drive been    repaired?
At least one hour, maybe longer.
And they managed to conceal it    from you.
You ordered me not to interfere    with them.
I also told you to watch them    carefully.
If we had assigned Jem'Hadar to do    the repairs, as I said --
I'm not interested in your    excuses.
Bring the warp drive on-line.
Wait!
Before we activate the warp drive    we should check the entire system    for possible sabotage.
That would take hours. Every    minute we spend in Federation    space exposes us to detection and    attack.
And I would hate for your last    mission to end in failure,    "Elder."        Do it.
When you have sufficient engine    power available, bring us to warp    four.
At least we're going to take them    with us.
Secure them with the other    prisoners.
Dax! At the upper rail!
I've got him.
This guy is really starting to get   on my nerves.
I've got torpedo lock!
Fire!
I'm flooding all compartments    except the engine room with    anesthezine gas.        Get that virus out of the computer    before somebody on the bridge    decides to engage the warp drive.
He should've listened to you and    killed me when he had the chance.
He was a First... they don't need    to... listen. Obedience brings...    Victory... and Victory is...
Mister Worf -- I think your wife's    here.

Captain's Log, Stardate 51492.3.    After completing repairs, we were    able to return to the anomaly and    successfully restore our runabout    and its crew to their normal size.    The surviving Jem'Hadar have been    transferred to a Federation P.O.W.    camp.
Is that your poem?
Yes.
Bloodwine.
Can I hear it?
It's not finished.
Please? Just the first line?
All right. But this is my first   poem.
I understand.
I have worked very hard and very   long on this.
I know.
And I do not wish to be...   ridiculed.
I promise.
Very well.       "This is the story... of the   little ship... that took a little   trip."       What do you think?
It's... uh... well... it rhymes.
You're putting me on!
There's nothing on this PADD!
Suddenly, there, right in front of    us, was this immense Jem'Hadar!
He looked as tall as a Seltan    Carnosaur. We were so close you    could see the veins throbbing in    his eyeballs.

(using his hands to     demonstrate)    We swung around and ducked behind    the operations console. I knew    that the first thing we had to do    was get our sensors back on-line.    So I told Julian --
Something wrong?
Are you sure that you've returned    to normal size?
Of course.
Hm.
Why?
You both appear to be a couple of    centimeters shorter than the last    time I saw you.
A changeling notices that sort of   thing.
I wasn't going to say anything,    but you do look a little on the...    petite side.
Infirmary.
And they say you don't have a    sense of humor.
